body:
I would keep two interfaces:

- `listen(port[, callback])`
- `listen(options[, callback])`

the first one is too much handy
What would be the effects of such confusion? What mistakes users would make?

> What would be the effects of such confusion? What mistakes users would make?

I think that people don't even realize more parameters are available for the `.listen` method. I think that is the biggest cause of people asking things like https://discord.com/channels/725613461949906985/725613462373269567/934671135482708139:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/321201/150988865-e65692fc-5e17-4dce-b667-2dd754551b7b.png)

Even though we specifically call out the reason for that, and the various method signatures, [in the docs](https://www.fastify.io/docs/latest/Reference/Server/#listen) I think people latch on to the first example. I think that by supporting _only_ the options object we will reduce that error, while also making our code easier to maintain. By forcing people to use the options object, I think they will be more likely to explore the full set of options available to the method.
I agree with @Eomm: passing just a port is so handy I would leave it as an option.

> I agree with @Eomm: passing just a port is so handy I would leave it as an option.

I think this completely negates the suggestion. Writing `.listen({ port: 8000 })` is not very difficult.

If I can add my two cents in here, I do agree with @jsumners that variadic interfaces can make everything more complicated, even more in an era where IntelliSense and auto-suggestions on Text Editors and IDEs are a thing where developers rely the most, meaning fewer visits to documentation and heavily relying on TS types for that (which is also quite bad but it is what it is).

Having a single argument can make some stuff easier in long term, and reduce the verbosity of the code a little, at least enough to simplify some stuff. I still need to visit quite often docs for Node.js core quite often because the same situation :)
I'm not sure how to make a decision here. Going on comment votes, I'd say the resolution passes. But actual comments puts it at 2 - 2.
I will go for a single object option. It just better for code maintenance.
Let me propose a slightly different take: we shift the examples everywhere to use the option object instead of the variadic arguments, and mark that our preferred way to call listen().
@mcollina That doesn't solve the maintenance part of the issue.

issue.title: Deprecate variadic listen method (closes #3652)

labels.name: v4.x
labels.description: Issue or pr related to Fastify v4

labels.name: missing types
labels.description: PR that does not implement TypeScript changes

repository.name: fastify
repository.description: Fast and low overhead web framework, for Node.js

issue.body:
Resolves #3652.

As I am going through the process of getting this PR together, I am more convinced that this is the right path. I have had to jump through several hoops to cover cases of "was this signature provided? That one? This one?", and deal with adding/removing coverage from tests. Once we get past the deprecation phase, the listen code will be simplified by virtue of completely removing that `normalizeListenArgs` function and the ceremony around feeding it.

Technically, as implemented, the signature is still variadic since it accepts a second, optional, parameter for the callback. Should we require the callback in the options object? This would be slightly odd in that it isn't a typical pattern. But we already internally support (and actually require) `listenOptions.cb` be defined when a callback is to be used.

#### Checklist

- [x] run `npm run test` and `npm run benchmark`
- [x] tests and/or benchmarks are included
- [x] documentation is changed or added
- [x] commit message and code follows the [Developer's Certification of Origin](https://github.com/fastify/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#developers-certificate-of-origin-11)
      and the [Code of conduct](https://github.com/fastify/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

issue.title: IPC server support

repository.name: fastify
repository.description: Fast and low overhead web framework, for Node.js

issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] I have written a descriptive issue title
- [X] I have searched existing issues to ensure the feature has not already been requested


###  Feature Proposal

Add `.listenIPC(path[, backlog])` method to listen on a named pipe or an UNIX domain socket.

### Motivation

In fasitfy@4 it is possible to create an [IPC server](https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v16.x/api/net.html#ipc-support) (i.e. server listening on a named pipe or an UNIX domain socket).

```js
const fastify = require('fastify')({ logger: true })

// https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v16.x/api/net.html#serverlistenpath-backlog-callback
fastify.listen('/path/to/socket.sock')
```

While this behavior is not documented, there are [type definitions](https://github.com/fastify/fastify/pull/2601) and [tests](https://github.com/fastify/fastify/blob/3709671b73c9109ef54fa1e85de0d7b7f7946226/test/listen.test.js#L186-L204).

However, it seems that we will not be able to use this method in v5 because variadic listen method is deprecated and will be removed. (#3652)

```
[FSTDEP011] FastifyDeprecation: Variadic listen method is deprecated. Please use ".listen(optionsObject)" instead. The variadic signature will be removed in `fastify@5`.
```

### Example

Create a Docker plugin:

```js
const fastify = require('fastify')({ logger: true })

fastify.get('/', async () => {
  return { status: 'TODO' }
})

fastify.listenIPC('/run/docker/plugins/myplugin.sock')
```

issue.title: Silence deprecation warning from fastify
issue.body:
The following message has been appearing in function logs:

[FSTDEP011] FastifyDeprecation: Variadic listen method is deprecated. Please use ".listen(optionsObject)" instead. The variadic signature will be removed in `fastify@5`.

Upstream issue and discussion: https://github.com/fastify/fastify/issues/3652

Fixes #385 

[GUS](https://gus.my.salesforce.com/one/one.app#/alohaRedirect/a07EE000014vMxvYAE)
